issuetype.description: A user story. Created by JIRA Software - do not edit or delete.
issuetype.name: Story

fields.summary: Hard coded regions preventing access to US GovCloud and US Ohio regions

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.
status.name: Resolved

issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

status.description: This issue is undergoing QA.  See linked QA issue(s) for progress.
status.name: In QA

fields.description: AWS has 14 regions as of October 2016, with more on the way (see https://aws.amazon.com/about-aws/global-infrastructure/).  The console should use an API call for the regions instead of hard-coding the list.

comments.body: One thought here. We could do what we added for federation on Euca. We could query regions for AWS the same way and not require adding new regions all the time. Now, a user cannot access the new region unless we enable it, or perhaps if they set that as the default in the console.ini (??). If we query regions, we get the current list and we could retain the "pretty" labels for regions we knew about at time of release.
[~dkavanagh]: Good suggestion on using DescribeRegions for AWS.  We should get this into 4.3, especially after reading https://aws.amazon.com/blogs/aws/in-the-works-aws-region-in-canada

AWS just announced the US East Ohio region, and there are a few more regions slated for launch within the next year, so we should strongly consider getting this into 5.0

/cc [~jloza]
Sounds good to me. I think we'll have time to do this.

https://github.com/eucalyptus/eucaconsole/pull/2223

We give up on pretty region names, but never have to update our app for regions.

Punting back to address two things:

1. We need to keep the configurable GovCloud region, per GUI-2839
2. We should keep the friendly region names.  I suggest a region id-to-label mapping, with the lookup falling back to the region ID if the label is missing.

PR has been updated.
One thing outstanding is that we don't use "pretty" region names. Ken and I discussed and decided to not use them so we could completely get out of updating the console as regions are added. We can discuss more in team meeting if necessary.
Punting back to restore friendly names to region selector.
Do you have more details? Which region? What were you doing when that happened?
I fired up the console and loaded the home page -- I wasn't logged in or able to log in.

I'm able to reproduce this on a CentOS7 source install. 
I was looking at the traceback an confused as to why this pertained to this branch.
I found a check that was dropped in this original change, now restored.
[~kgill] you dropped off IRC while we were discussing memcached in relation to this. Could you try running memcached to see if the problem goes away on your setup?

Maybe now some headway! I turned on boto debug and get this displayed:
    <Message>Could not find operation DescribeRegions for version 2014-10-01</Message>
Looking at version information. DescribeRegions has been there for ages.

Scrolling up more, I get other cases where it works:
2017-05-22 21:01:48,916 boto [DEBUG]:<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<DescribeRegionsResponse xmlns="http://ec2.amazonaws.com/doc/2014-10-01/">
    <requestId>6d0ad5ff-dba0-4324-a3eb-cd99c786614f</requestId>
    <regionInfo>
        <item>
I'm still observing the Error redirect loop with the latest changes in the GUI-2375 branch and with memcached enabled on Fedora 25.  Same result for Ubuntu (albeit without memcached).
I don't agree. Because we don't understand DescribeRegions failures makes it more concerning. I would not simply bail on this without understanding that fully. I'll work on that in the morning.
The root cause seems to be that the url used for the failed call had a "monitoring." prefix, not "ec2.". Will track that down.
[~kgill], please pull the latest. It should function correction, with or without memcached (though it is recommended, even for dev).
